1036.original:
H-0024.1
HOUSE BILL 1036
State of Washington
69th Legislature
2025 Regular Session
ByRepresentatives Ortiz-Self, Reed, Ramel, Doglio, Fosse, Peterson, Pollet, Nance, Berg, Ormsby, Scott, and Hill
Prefiled 12/11/24.Read first time 01/13/25.Referred to Committee on Postsecondary Education & Workforce.
AN ACT Relating to adding labor trustees to college boards; amending RCW 28B.50.100 and 28B.35.100; and providing an effective date.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
Sec. 1. RCW 28B.50.100 and 2013 c 23 s 58 are each amended to read as follows:
There is hereby created a board of trustees for each college district as set forth in this chapter. Each board of trustees shall be composed of five trustees, except as provided in RCW 28B.50.102, who shall be appointed by the governor for terms commencing October 1st of the year in which appointed. In making such appointments, the governor shall give consideration to geographical diversity, and representing labor, business, women, and racial and ethnic minorities, in the membership of the boards of trustees. The boards of trustees for districts ((containing technical colleges)) shall include at least one member from business and one member from labor.
The successors of the trustees initially appointed shall be appointed by the governor to serve for a term of five years except that any person appointed to fill a vacancy occurring prior to the expiration of any term shall be appointed only for the remainder of the term. Each member shall serve until a successor is appointed and qualified.
Every trustee shall be a resident and qualified elector of the college district. No trustee may be an employee of the community and technical college system, a member of the board of directors of any school district, or a member of the governing board of any public or private educational institution.
Each board of trustees shall organize itself by electing a chair from its members. The board shall adopt a seal and may adopt such bylaws, rules, and regulations as it deems necessary for its own government. Three members of the board shall constitute a quorum, but a lesser number may adjourn from time to time and may compel the attendance of absent members in such manner as prescribed in its bylaws, rules, or regulations. The district president, or if there be none, the president of the college, shall serve as, or may designate another person to serve as, the secretary of the board, who shall not be deemed to be a member of the board.
Each board of trustees shall follow procedures for open public meetings in chapter 42.30 RCW. Each board shall provide time for public comment at each meeting.
Members of the boards of trustees may be removed for misconduct or malfeasance in office in the manner provided by RCW 28B.10.500.
Sec. 2. RCW 28B.35.100 and 2006 c 78 s 3 are each amended to read as follows:
(1) The governance of each of the regional universities shall be vested in a board of trustees consisting of eight members, one of whom shall be a student and one of whom shall be a member from labor. The governor shall select the student member from a list of candidates, of at least three and not more than five, submitted by the governing body of the associated students. They shall be appointed by the governor with the consent of the senate and, except for the student member, shall hold their offices for a term of six years from the first day of October and until their successors are appointed and qualified. The student member shall hold his or her office for a term of one year from the first day of July and until the first day of July of the following year or until his or her successor is appointed and qualified, whichever is later. The student member shall be a full-time student in good standing at the respective university at the time of appointment.
(2) Five members of the board constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. In case of a vacancy, or when an appointment is made after the date of expiration of the term, the governor shall fill the vacancy for the remainder of the term of the trustee whose office has become vacant or expired.
(3) Except for the term of the student member, no more than the terms of two members will expire simultaneously on the last day of September in any one year.
(4) A student appointed under this section shall excuse himself or herself from participation or voting on matters relating to the hiring, discipline, or tenure of faculty members and personnel.
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 3. This act takes effect October 1, 2030.
--- END ---
1036.summary:
Purpose

The purpose of House Bill 1036 is to enhance the representation on college boards of trustees by including labor representatives. This bill amends existing laws related to the composition of trustees for college districts and regional universities. The key changes involve requiring each board to include at least one labor representative alongside other specified demographics aimed at promoting diversity. The impact of these changes is intended to ensure that the perspectives of the labor community are included in decision-making processes at educational institutions.

Key Provisions

College District Boards

  • Boards of trustees for each college district will consist of five members, appointed by the governor.
  • There must be at least one member representing labor and one member from business on boards that contain technical colleges.
  • Trustees will be appointed for a five-year term, and any vacancies will be filled only for the remainder of the term.
  • All trustees must be residents and qualified electors of the college district and cannot be employees of the community and technical college system.

Regional University Boards

  • Each board of trustees will consist of eight members, including one student and one labor representative.
  • The student member will be selected from candidates nominated by the associated student body and will serve a one-year term.
  • The other members, except for the student representative, will be appointed for six-year terms.
  • Five members of the board will constitute a quorum for conducting business.
  • Student members must excuse themselves from voting on matters related to faculty hiring and discipline.

Effective Date

  • The changes proposed in this act will take effect on October 1, 2030.

1036-S.summary:
Purpose

The primary goal of the edits made to Substitute House Bill 1036 is to refine the governance structure of college boards of trustees in Washington State by explicitly including labor representatives and clarifying the rules surrounding appointments and qualifications for trustees. Significant adjustments have been made to format, expand upon, and clarify certain provisions of the original bill. This will potentially enhance representation and oversight in these boards, thereby promoting a more balanced inclusion of diverse perspectives among trustees.

Key Changes

Structural Changes

  • The title of the bill has changed from "HOUSE BILL 1036" to "SUBSTITUTE HOUSE BILL 1036".
  • An additional section has been introduced through the amendment of RCW 28B.40.100, which pertains to The Evergreen State College's governance.

Membership and Trustee Qualifications

  • Additional specific conditions regarding membership have been provided:
    • More detailed requirements state that no trustee may be an employee of the higher education system or a governing board member of any educational institution (not just a community college).
    • The college board has the authority to adopt rules to clarify the appointment process for districts.

Appointment and Terms

  • Clarifications were made concerning the appointment process, including geographical diversity and representation.
  • The organization of boards and quorum requirements remain largely the same but have been better outlined, making it clearer how decisions can be made.

Public Participation

  • The substitute emphasizes that each board of trustees shall comply with open meeting procedures and provide for public comment at every meeting, reinforcing transparency.

These changes collectively aim to strengthen the governance of college boards by ensuring representation and adherence to public engagement standards.
